intro: Previously I was a data reporting fellow at the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University of Maryland, and a data and graphics intern at NBC News.
If you like to keep up with current events and care about the news ‚Äî or want to simply chat about trains or nerd out about antique fountain pens ‚Äî we should connect!

work.name: The Washington Post
work.title: News Designer, Design and Graphics Intern
work.desc: Collaborate with designers and graphics reporters to design and develop web presentations of enterprise projects. Build bespoke storytelling tools and components for the Post's website. Create interactive graphics for data-driven political stories.

work.name: Howard Center for Investigative Journalism
work.title: Fellow, Data Reporter
work.desc: Ran advanced data analyses in R and Python to develop promising leads and story ideas. Filed public records requests to gather data. Designed and built interactive graphics to supplement storytelling.

work.name: Capital News Service
work.title: Data and Graphics Reporter
work.desc: Designed graphics and programmed interactive maps and visualizations. Wrote Python web scrapers to automate data collection. Created news apps and long-form web presentations to present data-driven stories visually.

work.name: NBC News
work.title: Data Graphics Intern
work.desc: Pitched, reported and wrote data-driven stories. Analyzed data sets to develop story ideas. Built engaging charts, maps and graphics for stories to explain the news visually.

colophon: This website is created ‚Äî or "hand-made" ‚Äî by me to showcase my work, primarily. On days when I'm feeling particularly creative, it doubles as a playground for me to experiment with code.

This instance is scaffolded with the React-based framework, Next.js. The bulk of the content is written in a Google Doc, which functions as a micro CMS. ArchieML then formats the data as JSON, which is piped into the app. This helps me catch typos easily. A GitHub Action automatically builds and deploys this site to my FTP server when changes are pushed to the repository because I like automation.

I used VSCode as a code editor. iTerm2, an open-source framework for managing Zsh configurations, is my terminal emulator. The typeface used is system-ui, which results in Segoe on Windows, San Francisco on macOS, and Roboto on Android.
The site is designed to adapt to your device‚Äôs appearance ‚Äî dark mode or light mode ‚Äî settings.
I used Google Analytics for tracking page views.

Wondering what those circles at the top are? It‚Äôs a data visualization of the projects presented on this website. Each color represents my main role ‚Äî design, graphics, development, reporting, data analysis, or documentation ‚Äî in the project. The size of the circles maps to how many of those roles I played. One weekend I wanted to learn how to use d3-force and thought this was a good way to run an introductory experiment. I hope they add an element of fun to your experience navigating this site.
